lesson.title: Control Flow & Functions
lesson.summary: Learn some of the foundational programming concepts in R syntax.  These concepts include control flow, loops, and functions.

atoms.text:
### What's Ahead

In this lesson, we are going to take a look at the ways you can write your own functionality to solve problems in R.  When people use R, it is common that a function has already been created that solves a problem.  Searching the web, you can often find something to solve almost any type of problem.  

However, there are some cases where you might have to write your own functionality to solve certain problems.  For those cases, this lesson provides you with some tools to do those things.  Specifically, we will look at 
1. Control flow and conditional statements.
2. Loops
3. Functions

By the end of the lesson, you will have a better picture of how the functions you use with R were created.  Let's  get started!

# If/Else

If/else logic is used in code and in the world all around us.  Imagine we are pre-heating our oven to 425 degrees F.  When the temperature of the oven hits 425, we want to know.  However, if it isn't that hot yet, we will keep waiting.

# Example

First, we might create a couple of variables:

```undefined
oven.temp = NULL
is.it.ready.result1 = "It is ready!!!"
is.it.ready.result2 = "It isn't ready yet :("
```

I have stored `NULL` in our variables, as values that we will update later.

Now our if/else logic could be used in the following way:

```undefined
if (oven.temp == 425){
    print(is.it.ready.result1)
} else {
    print(is.it.ready.result2)
}
```

You can see the first thing we will do is check if the `oven.temp == 425`.  If it is, we print the first result, which I have created using 

```undefined
is.it.ready.result1 = "It is ready!!!"
```

If the temp isn't 425, then I print the second result

```undefined
is.it.ready.result2 = "It isn't ready yet :("
```

# Testing Example 1 Code

We could test to make sure our if/else statement works correctly by updating our NULL place holder with some other value.

```undefined
oven.temp = 385
is.it.ready.result1 = "It is ready!!!"
is.it.ready.result2 = "It isn't ready yet :("

if (oven.temp == 425){
    print(is.it.ready.result1)
} else {
    print(is.it.ready.result2)
}
```

This provides the output of 

```undefined
"It isn't ready yet :("
```

If you change the `oven.temp = 425`, you will see the correct result as: 

```undefined
"It is ready!!!"
```

# Example 2

We could add to this example by adding logic for if the `oven is too hot` (if it is hotter than 425), `not hot enough` (if it is less than 425), or `just right` (if it is equal to 425).

Updating our code for this example we might change our results to the following three

```undefined
is.it.ready.result1 = "oven is just right"
is.it.ready.result2 = "oven is too hot"
is.it.ready.result3 = "oven is not hot enough"
```

And then our logic might also be updated:

```undefined
if (oven.temp == 425){
    print(is.it.ready.result1)
} else if (oven.temp > 425) {
    print(is.it.ready.result2)
} else {
    print(is.it.ready.result3)
}
```

# Testing Example 2 Code

We could test to make sure our if/else statement works correctly by trying a few examples

```undefined
oven.temp = 385
is.it.ready.result1 = "oven is just right"
is.it.ready.result2 = "oven is too hot"
is.it.ready.result3 = "oven is not hot enough"

if (oven.temp == 425){
    print(is.it.ready.result1)
} else if (oven.temp > 425) {
    print(is.it.ready.result2)
} else {
    print(is.it.ready.result3)
}
```

This provides the output of 

```undefined
"oven is not hot enough"
```

If you change the `oven.temp = 425`, you will see the correct result as: 

```undefined
"oven is just right"
```

# Modular

Though not specifically related to if/else statements, understanding modular functionality is beneficial for the questions on the next page.  The modular command has the syntax of `%%`, and it is used to identify the remainder when one number is divided by another number.

For example, the result of the below is zero, because 15 is exactly divisible by 3.

```undefined
[Input]:  15 %% 3
[Output]: 0
```

However, the result of this is not zero, because 10 is not exactly divisible by 3

```undefined
[Input]:  10 %% 3
[Output]: 1
```

It is common to check if a value is exactly divisible by another using `%%` along with  `==`.

```undefined
[Input]:  10 %% 3 == 0
[Output]: FALSE
[Input]:  6 %% 3 == 0
[Output]: TRUE
```

This may come in handy for the second example on the next page!

# Remember

You can get a walkthrough of the notebooks by clicking on the green text.  There are multiple walkthroughs (actually 4 different videos as shown in the images below) on the next page, which are all related to the ideas on this page and in the overall lesson. 

Additionally, as you go about writing your solutions - note that there **is no one right answer.  If you watch my solution, it is just one way about solving the problem.  Your solution might even be better!**

You may also want to use the code on this page to assist with your solutions on the next page.  The syntax of where a `(` or `}` is can break your code, and most programmers in the real world copy and paste these items from elsewhere to simplify what logic they need to change.  No time to start these practices like the present!

Additionally, as you go about writing your solutions - note that there **is no one right answer.  If you watch my solution, it is just one way about solving the problem.  Your solution might even be better!**

You may also want to use the code on this page to assist with your solutions on the next page.  The syntax of where a `(` or `}` is can break your code, and most programmers in the real world copy and paste these items from elsewhere to simplify what logic they need to change.  No time to start these practices like the present!

# Loops One foundational topic of any programming language is the topic of loops. In R, you can write loops using the following syntax. Though spaces are not important, the parentheses `(`and curly braces `}` are important to have in the correct spots for your code to run. ```undefined for (val in 1:10){ print(val) } ``` This will print all values from 1 to 10. Notice again the parentheses and curly braces. All for loops will have this setup. ## Example 1 Often when creating for loops, it is useful to create variables that will be placeholders that are updated throughout the loop. If we want to sum all of the values from 2 to 7, we can change the above loop. ```undefined sum = 0 for (val in 2:7){ sum = sum + val } print(sum) ``` This line here ```undefined sum = sum + val ``` takes the previous `sum` value on the right side, adds `val`, and then stores this as a `sum` to be used on the next iteration of the loop. These iterations within the loop look like this: ```undefined sum + val __________ 0 + 2 2 + 3 5 + 4 9 + 5 ... ``` Notice the result of the previous line is the new sum (the first value on the next line). The `val` is being iterated through as the second number in each line. This is illustrated in the image below. ## Example 1 If instead of summing each of these values together, we wanted to store each sum in an array. We might create an empty vector that we can iterate through and store each sum. An example of this is shown in the code below. ```undefined sums = NULL idx = 1 sum = 0 for (val in 2:7){ sum = sum + val # calculates new sum sums[idx] = sum # stores sum in sums vector idx = idx + 1 # iterates to next index in the vector } ``` Using `sums = NULL` means that we can define how `sums` works when we need to use it. This is a nice placeholder until we use it in our function. Then the `idx` value can point at a particular index in our vector which is where we store the next sum. ```undefined idx = idx + 1 ``` Since `idx = 1` at the start of our code, the first `sum` value will go in the first index, then the above line changes this to the second index, and we put the second `sum` in that line. The result then is a vector of these `sum` values. ```undefined [Input]: sums [Output]: 2 5 9 14 20 27 ```

initial_code_files.name: forLoop.r

atoms.text:
# Functions

## Introduction

In the previous video, you had your first introduction to functions.  Functions are one of the most powerful tools for any programmer, as they allow you to build a general solution that can be used.

Although you haven't been writing your own functions up to this point in the class, you have been using functions that someone else wrote.

Just a few of the many examples of functions you have used up to this point include:

1. summary()  - takes in a **dataframe** as an **argument** and **returns** a **summary**
1. dim() - takes in a **dataframe** as an **argument** and **returns** the** number of rows and columns**
1. head() - takes in a **dataframe** as an **argument** and **returns** the** first few rows**

## Defining Your Own Functions

 You saw in the previous video syntax that would allow you to create your own functions.  Specifically, there is a keyword  `function`.

If we want to create a function that always returns **"Hello"**, we can create this in the following way:

```undefined
sayHello = function(){
    return("Hello")
}
```

Whatever is beside `return` will be given back when the function is run.  In order to run the function, you simply use the name provided on the left side of the equal sign with parentheses following as shown below.

```undefined
[Input]:  sayHello()
[Output]: "Hello"
```

## Arguments

However, the real power of functions is created when you introduce **arguments**.  Arguments are the values that are provided to the function.

For our `sayHello` function, we might want to be specific about who we are saying hello to, and we could introduce an argument that would allow for this specificity as shown here:

```undefined
sayHello = function(to.who){
    result = paste("Hello", to.who, sep=" ")
    return(result)
}
```

We can then  use this function to say hello to my friend `"Mohit"`.

```undefined
[Input]:  sayHello("Mohit")
[Output]: "Hello Mohit"
```

## Default Arguments

In many cases, we provide the arguments of functions with default values.  These values are used when no value is provided, but you can also write over the default values with your own argument values.

Let's look at this in practice in the below function, where I place **Mohit **as the **default argument**.  You can see this with the `to.who = "Mohit"` line when creating the function definition.

```undefined
sayHello = function(to.who = "Mohit"){
    result = paste("Hello", to.who, sep=" ")
    return(result)
}
```

This means that if we are saying hello specifically to **Mohit**, we don't need to provide a value at all in the `to.who` argument.  See the result below using this new default.

```undefined
[Input]:  sayHello()
[Output]: "Hello Mohit"
```

However, we can also overwrite with a new name.

```undefined
[Input]:  sayHello("Jennifer")
[Output]: "Hello Jennifer"
```

# Passing And Creating Arguments in Functions

There are actually a few different ways we might pass arguments to a function.  At a high level, these are 

1. By default

2. By position

3. By Name

Let's look at how this works in practice.  Consider the function below, which is pretty close to the function you saw in the previous text.

```undefined
happyGreet = function(greeting.type = "Hello", to.who = "Mohit"){
    result = paste(greeting.type, to.who, sep=" ")
    return(result)
}
```

You can see the function is `happyGreet`, which has two arguments: `greeting.type` and `to.who`.

## Passing Arguments by Default

The first way that we can pass arguments is by default.  In this case, the starting values in the function will be used, and no other values need to be provided to the function.

Here is an example using our happyGreet function.

```undefined
[Input]:  happyGreet()
[Output]: "Hello Mohit"
```

## By Position

You might also decide to pass argument values by position.  Since the order of the arguments when we created the function is as shown here:

```undefined
greeting.type = "Hello", to.who = "Mohit"
```

We can pass the arguments to our function in this order without having to say what the name of the argument is.  

```undefined
[Input]:  happyGreet("Good Bye", "Jennifer")
[Output]: "Good Bye Jennifer"
```

We could also just change the greeting, but keep the default `to.who` value.  However, we cannot do the opposite using "by position" arguments.

```undefined
[Input]:  happyGreet("Good Bye") # this uses the default second argument
[Output]: "Good Bye Mohit"
```

## By Name

The final, and most explicit, way to pass arguments to a function is by name.   With this method, the order of the arguments doesn't matter and arguments not provided will use default values.  Below are a few different ways you can pass an argument by name to a function.

```undefined
[Input]:  happyGreet(greeting.type = "Buenos dias", to.who = "Kathy")
[Output]: "Buenos dias Kathy"

[Input]:  happyGreet(to.who = "Kathy", greeting.type = "Buenos dias")
[Output]: "Buenos dias Kathy"

[Input]:  happyGreet(to.who = "Kathy")
[Output]: "Hello Kathy"

[Input]:  happyGreet(greeting.type = "Buenos dias")
[Output]: "Buenos dias Mohit"
```

You can see the order doesn't matter, and you can leave out arguments that you want to use the default.

complex_prompt.text: Match each function to title to its name in the above function.

question.prompt:
What is the result of running:
> addValues()

answers.text: Nothing, you need to provide starting argument values.
Error.  There is a syntax or other issue with the code.

question.prompt:
What is the result of running

> addValues(2)

answers.text: Error.  There are two arguments, but you only passed one value.
Nothing.  You need to provide more information to the function, but it won't break.

question.prompt:
What is the result of running

> addValues(2, 5)

What is the result of running

> addValues(ending.val = 3, starting.val= 2)

answers.text: Error.  Since the arguments are in the wrong order.
Nothing.  The arguments are in the wrong order, but it won't break.
